Or in This Case Lack Thereof

464 words written on Tue, Nov 12 2002

I‚Äôm having a hard time finding good stories lately. I don‚Äôt know, maybe I‚Äôm pickier or something.

Last four movies I saw, for example:

  • The Transporter‚Äîan action film, no story, no story expected, no biggie; and damn good action so there you go.
  • White Oleander‚Äîcan‚Äôt put my finger on it, but I didn‚Äôt like this story; it‚Äôs not the story itself, but the way it was told‚Ä¶just didn‚Äôt work for some reason.
  • Frida‚Äîsaw this one last night, and I must give it the break that I had high expectations; I normally love movies about artists; but this one wasn‚Äôt really about her as an artist; but it wasn‚Äôt really about her as a cripple, or a bisexual, or a betrayed wife either. I‚Äôm unsure if another hour would‚Äôve made it a better movie, a different lead, a different screenplay. Again, I can‚Äôt put my finger on it. Good but not great.
  • Femme Fatale‚Äîlast night we were going to ‚Äúdouble feature‚Äù 8 Mile, but they were checking tickets at the door of the actual theatre, so we went into this one. This one was very weird. It tried to be cool and smart and mess with your head, but again, it just didn‚Äôt pull it off. Good idea, bad execution.

Also, I saw The Shipping News on DVD. Now that‚Äôs based on a Pulitzer-winning book, so there you go. They could‚Äôve dealt better with the frontstory in the movie, though, and easily made it an hour longer (and that much better).

And books:

  • Requiem‚Äîsupposedly one of the best non-linear stories, but not only scattered like crazy, where you couldn‚Äôt keep ahold of one thread until it came back around again, but the actual threads were too weird to have much continuity within themselves. My non-linear story theory is a little bit different.
  • Travelling Mercies, by Anne Lamott‚Äîwas great, really great, for the first half, then it got more and more whiney until I had to give up about 2-3 chapters from the end. When your wife is truly suffering, in true pain all day long every day, you just can‚Äôt stand to hear some self-absorbed middle-aged woman go on crying about how her son puts her out or she has bad hairdays sometimes.
  • If Nobody Speaks of Remarkable Things‚ÄîOk, two huge caveats‚Äî1: I‚Äôve met the author and heard him speak and I know he‚Äôs a very cool, humble cat. 2: I‚Äôm only .25 the way thru it. But only one thing has happened yet. It reminds me of what Chuck was saying in Lullaby, the best way to forget something is to get lost in the details. Oh yeah, apparently the whole book is only one day‚Ä¶But it‚Äôs ok, all British stories are slow for some reason. Must be the weather.
